title: Translational Immunobiology
description:
This course is designed to introduce immunobiology Ph.D. students to translational research and medicine. The course is arranged in modules, each of which focuses on a specific disease with a conspicuous immunological component. Each module consists of (1) didactic sections: covering disease phenotype, underlying immunobiology and pathology, and mechanisms of treatment approaches including their limitations; (2) patient contact: the view of the disease from the patient's perspective including symptoms and treatment options; and (3) clinical section: taking place in the hospital environment, where students are exposed to disease management approaches. The combination of medical knowledge and personal interaction with patients and their physicians provides a new perspective to immunobiology Ph.D. students that will broaden their basic science training and enable them to work more confidently at the interface of research and medicine and facilitate collaborations with clinical investigators. Enrollment limited to twenty-five.

Prerequisites: IBIO 530a and 531b.
